thread.title: WSDOT files lawsuit against Seattle Tunnel Partners
thread.title_full: WSDOT files lawsuit against Seattle Tunnel Partners | www.kirotv.com

author: KIRO 7 STAFF
title: WSDOT files lawsuit against Seattle Tunnel Partners
text:
The Washington State Department of Transportation has filed a lawsuit against Seattle Tunnel Partners, the group working with the Bertha drilling machine to create the Alaskan Way Viaduct replacement tunnel.
The suit, filed Friday in King County Superior Court, was prompted by recent court filings by STP and their insurance companies, according to a WSDOT statement.
Despite the lawsuit, the transportation department said it is committed to working with Seattle Tunnel Partners to complete the Seattle tunnel project.
“Filing this lawsuit ensures WSDOT will have a right to make legal claims in the future. This lawsuit does not prevent STP from pursuing claims under the terms of the design-build contract,” WSDOT said in a statement.
“Taking action to preserve WSDOT’s rights in court was a necessary step. Our focus remains on completing the project, and removing the seismically vulnerable Alaskan Way Viaduct. We intend to ask for a stay of WSDOT’s lawsuit until the project is completed and asked STP to join us in this request.”
WSDOT staff says the action is to protect the interests of Washington taxpayers.
The lawsuit will allow for work on the State Route 99 Tunnel Project to be completed before litigation takes place, according to WSDOT.
The filing comes after the announcement that WSDOT says it expects to lose $78 million because the machine digging the tunnel to replace the Alaskan Way Viaduct in Seattle broke down.
The $78 million cost reflects extra spending on administrators, engineers, consulting firms and office space as a two-year delay because of continuing problems with the Bertha tunnel-boring machine.
